items.title: AttributeError  at /en/pdf/ 'tuple' object has no attribute 'endswith'
items.body:
I wanted to start with the example from the documentation and just modified path instead of url. Here is the code:

```
from django.urls import path, include
from django.conf.urls.i18n import i18n_patterns
from wkhtmltopdf.views import PDFTemplateView

urlpatterns = [
    path("i18n/", include("django.conf.urls.i18n")),
]
urlpatterns += i18n_patterns(
    path("pdf/", PDFTemplateView.as_view(template_name='my_app/pdf/invoice.html', filename='my_pdf.pdf'), name="pdf"),
)
```

If I try to visit the url I get the error from the Title.

Can somebody help me please.

items.title: Django 3 support
items.body:
I have tried to run django-wkhtmltopdf with the latest Django development version and there is a change where `six` has been removed:  (django/django@4138481 / https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/27753)

Version of Django 3.0 ~~due to be released until~~ was [released](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.0/releases/3.0/) at 2. December.

```
ImportError: cannot import name 'six' from 'django.utils' (virtualenvs/lib/python3.7/site-packages/django/utils/__init__.py)

virtualenvs/lib/python3.7/site-packages/wkhtmltopdf/utils.py:24: ImportError
```

Is it meant to be this way ?

            'header-html':'/home/header.html',

            'margin-top': 100,
            } )
`

items.title: Usage of load-error-handling and load-media-error-handling fails because they are considered flags
items.body:
These options are considered flags, as we can inspect here:

https://github.com/incuna/django-wkhtmltopdf/blob/master/wkhtmltopdf/utils.py#L40

But wkhtmltopdf expect them to have options, as we can see in the documentation:

```
      --load-error-handling <handler> Specify how to handle pages that fail to
                                      load: abort, ignore or skip (default
                                      abort)
      --load-media-error-handling <handler> Specify how to handle media files
                                      that fail to load: abort, ignore or skip
                                      (default ignore)
```

For now, I just downgraded to wkhtmltopdf 3.1.0, but I will fix it this week and check closely all other flags ignored by the commit f62662e6, to make sure we don't have any other like these :)

items.title: The uploaded images do not appear in the pdf
items.body:
Hello, I have a problem with the rendering of the pdf.

In my project, I have the static files in the /static/ directory and the uploaded images in the /media/ directory. Static files do not bother me, but uploaded images does not appear in the pdf. If I add in the url ?as=html the images are displayed correctly but in the pdf it does not appear.

I tried the urls of this type:

- /media/_versions/images/alimentation/bobbin-1862555_1920_big.jpg
- http://domain.tld/media/_versions/images/alimentation/bobbin-1862555_1920_big.jpg
- /home/project/www/media/_versions/images/alimentation/bobbin-1862555_1920_big.jpg

My settings vars:

```
WKHTMLTOPDF_CMD_OPTIONS = {
    'quiet': True,
}

if not DEBUG:
    WKHTMLTOPDF_CMD = "xvfb-run wkhtmltopdf"

BASE_DIR = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)))

STATIC_URL = '/static/'

if DEBUG:
    STATICFILES_DIRS = (os.path.join('static'),)
else:
    STATIC_ROOT = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, 'static')

MEDIA_URL = '/media/'
MEDIA_ROOT = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, 'media/')

```

Can you help me please ?

                                       show_content_in_browser=False,
                                       cmd_options={'margin-top': 2, }
                                       )
        return response
```

items.title: The fix for null request in earlier Django versions produces no context processor
items.body:
Hi,
the fix for null request makes the context be treated as a Context, instead of a RequestContext, because you don't pass the request for context generation (line 304 of utils.py) at least in Django 1.8

Cheers

items.title: TypeError: render() takes exactly 2 arguments (3 given)
items.body:
django-wkhtmltopdf==3.1.0
Django==1.8.17

Django 1.8+ takes exactly 2 arguments `(self, context)` to the `render()` method => https://github.com/django/django/blob/stable/1.8.x/django/template/base.py#L204

So, this condition is invalid: https://github.com/incuna/django-wkhtmltopdf/blob/master/wkhtmltopdf/utils.py#L293 makes rendering failed.

items.title: Pdf does not include svg-file
items.body:
I have a template with an image of an empty form in the background, and divs positioned to fill out the empty blanks from context in the foreground.

The template is rendered by django as it should, and the pdf is produced, but without the image.

The html-code to include the image file is this: The property "data" is referencing the svg-file:

`div id="pg1" style="-webkit-user-select: none;"><object width="909" height="1286" data="/path/to/image.svg" type="image/svg+xml" id="pdf1" style="width:909px; height:1286px; background-color:white; -moz-transform:scale(1); z-index=0</object>`

Is there an obvious solution to this?

items.title: Blank first page of output
items.body:
I have a relatively simple view that extends a class based view that gets context data from a model, and spits out two html tables with the data, stacked on top of each other. I'm using bootstrap to add striped formatting to the tables. The view looks exactly as expected when using the `?as=html` parameter, and it looks exactly as expected in the PDF output, except the first page is always blank. I've tried changing the margins in the cmd_options of the pdf class, as well as a ton of other `wkhtmltopdf` parameters, but have not been able to get rid of the blank page. I'm at a loss as to what to try next to fix this. wkhtmltopdf-- v0.12.3 (with patched qt) on Mac OS X latest django-wkhtmltopdf django 1.9.9 Below is the HTML template (with the table rows removed) ```

Costs

Price
```

items.title: CalledProcessError are really hard to debug (or how to catch CalledProcessError)
items.body:
Hi !

I generate fairly complex PDFs (with openlayer maps making ajax calls) and have trouble debugging them. I often get `CalledProcessError` because of different things, and the only way I found to see the actual command line errors that happened is to copy and paste the display command in the terminal.
But it is time consuming and some other error can happen (permissions error, etc.)

Is there a way to display the command line errors of a failing PDFTemplateResponses call directly in the browser ?

I expected something like this: 

```
try:
        return PDFTemplateResponse(...)
except Exception as e:
        return HttpResponse('didnt work ! '+str(e))
```

But the exception isn't catched !

Thanks !

Olivier

items.title: Installing django-wkhtmltopdf fails on fresh requirement install
items.body:
A lot of travis like environments (like GitLab CI) always install all requirements for testing purposes and often use twelve-factor configuration with environment variables. (http://12factor.net/)

This code in will fail on install because Django is not installed yet:
https://github.com/incuna/django-wkhtmltopdf/blob/master/wkhtmltopdf/__init__.py#L2-L3

A better way must be provided to ensure the installation of the product. 
A quick-and-dirty way is to use a try/catch ImportError.

```
try:
    if 'DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE' in os.environ:
        from .utils import *
except ImportError:
    pass
```

items.title: Cannot use other template engines since version 3.0
items.body:
In version 3.0, a lot of code was refactored, including `render_to_temporary_file()` (see PR #95). In that function, `context` is now converted into a `Context` object, which is a class related to Django's template language.

Django 1.8 introduced pluggable template engines and I had no problems using Jinja2 with version 2.0.3 of django-wkhtmltopdf.

This new code in `render_to_temporary_file()` causes problems with other template engines:

``` python
# make sure the context is a context object
if not isinstance(context, (Context, RequestContext)):
    context = Context(context)

content = smart_text(template.render(context))
```

The `render()` method, according to [DEP 182](https://github.com/django/deps/blob/master/final/0182-multiple-template-engines.rst#backends-api), is actually supposed to take a `dict`. The DTL backend's `Template` class handles converting the `dict` to a `Context` or `RequestContext`.

Can this template engine dependency be removed?

I noticed issue #100 discusses warnings that are the result of the some of the changes above. I raised a separate issue since 3.0 is no longer usable for users of other template engines.

Thanks for your help.

items.body: App loading changes introduced with Django 1.7 prevent the tests from running when `AppRegistryNotReady` is raised.

items.title: CalledProcessError return exit code -11
items.body:
I've tested several what is the cause of problem. There are 3 factors I could think of. Architecture, Django web server, and wkhtmltopdf version.
1. Ubuntu 12.04 32 bit, FastCGI, Build from source 0.12.1 => Work!
2. Ubuntu 12.04 32 bit, uWSGI, Build from source 0.12.1 => Work!
3. Ubuntu 14.10 64 bit, FastCGI, Build from source 0.12.1 => Work!
4. Ubuntu 14.10 64 bit, uWSGI, Build from source 0.12.1 => Doesn't Work!
5. Ubuntu 14.10 64 bit, python manage.py runserver, Build from source 0.12.1 => Work!
6. Ubuntu 14.10 64 bit, FastCGI, Download from website 0.12.2 => Work!
7. Ubuntu 14.10 64 bit, uWSGI, Download from website 0.12.2 => Doesn't Work!
8. Ubuntu 14.10 64 bit, python manage.py runserver, Build from source 0.12.1 => Work!

Summary from above:
1. Use FastCGI (It is going to deprecate when Django 1.9 comes) or python manage.py runserver always WORK!
2. If architecture is 64 bit, it wont' WORK with uWSGI.

I would love to see uWSGI could work on 64 bit server.

items.title: Issues #15 and #16 re-emerge with Python 3 and mod_wsgi?
items.body:
Issues #15 and #16, fixed by pull 40 (https://github.com/incuna/django-wkhtmltopdf/pull/40) has re-emerged with Python3
This is an issue of compatibility between python3.4 and mod_wsgi, and had been reported and acknowledged: GrahamDumpleton/mod_wsgi#85

Not sure yet best way to patch django-wkhtmltopdf so it can detect the condition that mod_wsgi has replace sys.stderr.  Probably with a try:  except: block.   I will offer up a pull-request once I settle on a nice solution.

items.title: use updated URL for wkhtmltopdf downloads
items.body:
Hello,

wkhtmltopdf has [moved the downloads provider](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/wkhtmltopdf-general/wZwTUol3mXI/GNVeyrKDdqIJ) from SourceForge to gna.org. As mentioned in the linked message, all earlier downloads have been removed from SourceForge and you are strongly advised to migrate to the new URLs. The following files in your repository will need to be updated:
- .travis.yml

It is recommended to either subscribe to the [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/wkhtmltopdf-general) or [Twitter feed](https://twitter.com/wkhtmltopdf) to receive updates on new releases and further changes.

Thanks,
wkhtmltopdf maintainer

items.title: Cannot connect to X server
items.body:
On headless servers, wkhtmltopdf throws the error:

```
cannot connect to X server
```

The solution, as outlined [here](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9604625/wkhtmltopdf-cannot-connect-to-x-server), is to wrap it with `xvfb-run`, e.g.

```
xvfb-run --server-args="-screen 0, 1024x768x24" wkhtmltopdf file1.html file2.pdf
```

Is this supported with django-wkhtmltopdf? Looking through the code, I see I can override the command by adding a Dango setting like:

```
WKHTMLTOPDF_CMD = 'xvfb-run --server-args="-screen 0, 1024x768x24" wkhtmltopdf'
```

However, it still throws a CalledProcessError exception like:

```
Command '['xvfb-run', '--server-args="-screen', '0,', '1024x768x24"', 'wkhtmltopdf', '--collate', '--encoding', u'utf8', '--orientation', u'landscape', '--quiet', '/tmp/wkhtmltopdfe0XRd8.html', '-']' returned non-zero exit status 1
```

Oddly, when I ran that command manually:

```
xvfb-run --server-args="-screen 0, 1024x768x24" wkhtmltopdf --collate --encoding utf8 --orientation landscape --quiet /tmp/wkhtmltopdfe0XRd8.html -
```

it runs without error, so I'm not sure what the actual error is. Why would django-wkhtmltopdf be unable to run that command? I received that error from Django's dev server, which runs as my user and so that tmp file was created by my user account, so it shouldn't be a permissions issue.

items.title: checkbox and radio inputs are bigger than with command-line
items.body:
Hi,

First, many thanks for this great project!
I'm facing a rather strange issue: PDF documents generated with _django-wkhtmltopdf_ don't exactly look the same as those generated with the command line. To be more precise, checkboxes and radio buttons look bigger when using django.
Of course, I took care of comparing in the exact same conditions : same HTML input file (using the one dynamically generated in /tmp), and same command-line arguments (`--quiet --encoding utf8` if I'm right).

Even more weird: it seems to be related to _wkhtmltopdf_ upgrade a few days ago (now 0.12.1). And using either version 2.0.1 or 2.0.2 of _django-wkhtmltopdf_ doesn't change anything...

As a result, I spent hours to design a document, in order to have it fit in one page, and now it is on 2 pages... :-(

I couldn't find any workaround, as CSS is useless for checkboxes and radios, and I couldn't have the --checkbox-svg options work with command-line to override the output.

I looked in the source code, but I cannot understand why `django-wkhtmltopdf` would create such a difference. I'm lost... do you see any explanation for this ?

Cheers

Has anyone tried to transform a HTML/JS page, with AJAX calls, into a PDF?. So, I suppose that the problem is related to the step where the temporary files are created, does any one have any idea where or what should I analyze in order to find a solution?.

Thanks!!

items.title: make_absolute_paths() func in utils.py does not test for empty strings in MEDIA_ROOT or MEDIA_URL
items.body:
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/settings/#media-root

The default values for MEDIA_ROOT and MEDIA_URL are empty string. In projects where these still have default values, the PDF file ends up being just a large list of strings that say "file://". The regex replaces nearly every string in the html with "file://"

Please test for empty strings in the "overrides" list

But when I have a clean html document (without reference to the static file) is generated correctly.

items.title: Multi-page/template PDFs
items.body:
Hi,

I've recently adapted this library (code not on Github yet) to support the adding of more than one page (i.e. multiple templates) to generate a PDF. I just want to gauge whether others need this as well, because then I will make an effort to contribute this code back to the library.

I had the need to generate a PDF with multiple pages, with each page coming from a different template. So I created an extra class that can contain multiple template names, and assigned an instance of this class to the "template_name" variable. To make it compatible with Django, that class has to return only the first template name in it's **str** representation. Therein also lies the one restriction: The multiple pages are only generated if the content is rendered to PDF. If it's rendered to the browser, only the first "page" is shown. But in my case, the requirement is for PDFs only.

Does it make sense to "retrofit" the library with this feature? Let me know. :)

items.title: Fix well-ranked StackOverflow answer
items.body:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7821087/django-pdf-export/7854260#7854260

Putting this here so I don't forget it. We've had at least two people find my answer and get confused since the answer is horrendously out of date.

Need to update to reflect our move to CBVs (and how you can use functional views still).

items.title: Fix pdf download default
items.body:
The standard browser flow for this has always been to render PDF links unless a special header was passed to force the download.

In the last few years (~4 IIRC?) Chrome and Firefox (I've not used IE since 2002 so have no idea about that) have been rendering PDFs within the browser since they're a ISO format and really just markup under the hood.

We need to swap this default to not set the download header and follow what would be expected by users who are unfamiliar with the inner workings of the library.

Since this is a backwards incompatible change we'll also need to make a major release and document the change correctly.

items.title: Release a new version
items.body:
Last release was 4 months ago, we've had a few useful little contributions since then.

- [x] push to PyPI

items.title: Image fields' URLs aren't being correctly generated (prepended with 6 file://<home directory path>)
items.body:
I have a Django model with a ImageField, and I'm trying to use PDFTemplateView to generate a PDF that includes that image. However, the image URL isn't being properly generated in the PDF. If I put something like this in my template:

{{ user.get_profile.company.logo.url }}

This gets properly converted if I request it in HTML (with ?as=html):

/media/logos/abcfinancialservices.png

But if I'm generating the PDF I get this instead: file:///Users/amatosfile:///Users/amatosfile:///Users/amatosfile:///Users/amatosfile:///Users/amatos/media/logos/abcfinancialservices.png So basically I'm getting my home directory prepended 6 times in the URL. I haven't had more time to look into it, but it looks like a bug. Or I'm doing anything wrong? I'm not that familiar with Django, but assuming it's a bug I'm happy to submit a patch if I can get some guidance -I just need some brief explanation of what the problem might be.

items.title: Had a problem with renderding unicode
items.body:
GB Pound sign £ didn't work with pdf nginx/uswsgi on ubuntu 11.04, even though added utf meta tag as per docs, and it worked fine on dev box.

Managed to fix it by changing views.py, line 87, in render_to_temporary_file

```
tempfile.write(content)
```

to

```
tempfile.write(content.encode('UTF-8'))
```

items.title: Change location of tests (again)
items.body:
Ok, so on comparison with some other projects and discussion with jezdez, I think we should opt for a compromise solution.

Tests should be included under `wkhtmltopdf.tests.*`, which acts as a sub-app which contains the tests and all necessary other files and so they run if and only if you add `wkhtmltopdf.tests` to your `INSTALLED_APPS`.

This means you can run the tests for the third part app on your installation easily to check everything's working nicely, but if you choose to patch the app, or want a leaner test suite you don't have to have it. As our test suite grows, it'll get slower as we're hitting the file system and running slow binaries.

Seems the best of both worlds.

[Reference example can be found [on celery-haystack](https://github.com/jezdez/celery-haystack/tree/795d37450815c680e4f936f2ba2ff77d882dd3a0/celery_haystack/tests)]

items.title: Do some real world testing of v1.0 release candidates
items.body:
I've cleaned out the junk code, fixed the tests (I think) and pushed a release candidate to our internal PyPI (should I put this on the real pypi too - I think maybe not as pip install will pick it up as the most recent version)

If everyone can have a play with it and check it works - in particular @meshy as you're on a different OS and so different binaries.

items.title: wrong import at __init__.py
items.body:
`from .utils import *`

should be 

`from utils import *`

items.title: Look up binary path in env
items.body: When looking for the binary path we should check for it in the env as well as `settings.py`

items.title: Document which binary you need better
items.body:
Provide links to the current versions for OSX and Ubuntu, preferably with example installation instructions.

I guess it's a really bad idea to bundle the binary with the distro...?

items.title: Deprecated views need to be removed when we go to v1.0
